reviewText:
If you like simulating hockey this game is great. It has a deep game sim engine, and pretty decent options to customize the experience to your liking. Don't expect it to do everything, but it does what it says it will do quite well. If you bought FHM 2014 and are now on the fence about this game, I'd say give it a chance. It's drastically different from FHM 2014, and has no errors or issues so far.

I have been waiting for this game for the last couple of months to come out. I have followed the build-up to the game's release quite closely, seeing what the beta testers and developers had to say about it, and it's expectations. I played FHM 2014, and was disappointed by it as many were, but the developers have done a wonderful job this time around. They have built a very solid game, and have not overstretched themselves by marketing something beyond what they said they would do. In fact, Sebastian, the lead developer on the project, has time and time again undersold the game on the game's forums, likely trying to temper expectations after the release of the last FHM title.

But anyways, I haven't had any issues with this game yet, and the way it was so strenuously tested I don't anticipate having any major issues. I'm sure there are bugs here and there to be found, but it's definitely a solid release.

They plan to release this game annually after this year, and it's likely if there aren't features you're looking for in this release, they'll be added in subsequent versions.

But having played EHM:EA I can honestly say there's no alternative to FHM 2.

10/10

reviewText:
As someone who really was excited to play the first FHM game and, despite its many flaws, still sunk in a ton of hours into playing it, I was ecstatic about the sequel for a long while. When I got invited to help beta test for it the past couple months on the forum to iron out bugs, I was even more excited. So don't let the low number of hours fool you, I've played the game a lot already prior to the release here on Steam.

With that said I can safely say this game is leaps and bounds above what the first game was. If you had a bad experience with FHM 2014, don't let that sway you at all. This is like a whole different game in terms of how much was done to fix and chnage everything. Fictional mode (my preferred mode personally) is far more stable, as now it only will run your league and its affiliates, no background leagues to slow you down. The facegen really helps in making players stand out and come to life a little more, you can add in custom jerseys for the teams through mods along with logos and pictures, the new game engine is much improved as it takes into account different player roles to rate them better during games. On top of that you've got new tactics management and a generally better AI for lines and rosters.

If you are a hockey fan or fan of the OOTP team as a whole, you will not be disappointed in this game. It is very worth the long wait it took, and having tested the game I've seen how hard they worked to make sure it was close to perfect at release. This is truly the game we had hoped for before.

reviewText:
tl;dr - This game is for die-hard hockey fans only in its current state; everyone else should play OOTP15.

Out of the Park Baseball is one of, if not the best management sim on the market, so when I found out the team behind it had made a hockey game, I was intrigued; when I saw it on sale, I had to give it a shot, hoping for the same kind of deep, rewarding, limitlessly customizable experience I got from their baseball sim.

I've had a good time, and I'll most likely keep playing, but I haven't gotten that same experience.

While the customization is there for leagues, teams, and players, it's not there for the AI like it is in OOTP, meaning players are stuck with some utterly ridiculous trade proposals from the computer offering spare parts for significantly better players and refusing to accept any deal that isn't painfully lopsided in its favor. Granted, I could play in Commissioner Mode, which would allow me to force trades through (just like OOTP), but it's the principle of the thing.

The menu system also feels a generation behind that of OOTP. It's rather clunky and takes some getting used to. That's before players ever reach the bizarre game screen which makes all the information very difficult to digest, especially when the game is moving along at the normal speed of a hockey game or faster.

Other than that, complaints are minor. Little things that get missed in some of the nuances of each league, which are irritating and, at some levels, even game-breaking. But, you know what? It's hockey. And if it's playable, I'm willing to overlook some of its flaws to get some enjoyment out of it. And, despite my complaints, I have enjoyed FHM2. Go Preds.

reviewText:
There are a lot of wonderful things about FHM2. Unfortunately the wonderful things are outweighed by some unbelievably poorly thought-out flaws. You manage a hockey team. You draft and trade players to build up the team over time. Your effort is made futile by the AI very often taking spontaneous control of your trading and management of the team. It's very absurd.

You make a chart of what positions you need to trade for to have a shot at the cup this year but - WHOA! The AI takes charge and trades for three mediocre defencemen! Sure you checked off that box saying you're in control of trades, setting the lines, etc., but that box does nothing. No problem: You're lucky and you saved the game recently. So all you have to do is spend an hour redoing the entry draft and then WHOA! the AI just traded away that goalie you've been developing for three years! Let's go back to your last save game and redo that entry draft again. And again. And again.

The point of the game is developing a team over a number of seasons but, regardless of your performance, the AI constantly interferes. I've played five seasons of this Kafkaesque nightmare and I'm calling it quits. Outrageously poor design for a sports management game.

Yes, I've played this game for 172 hours. Don't make my mistake.

reviewText:
Franchise Hockey Manager 2 made by Out Of The Park Baseball Developments, is a much better and clean game to its first game Franchise Hockey Manager 2014. While saying that, there are still some problems with this game, but not major ones and not as close to as bad as to FHM 2014's probelms. OK, lets start off with the positives of this game. FHM 2 now has a completely new engine that looks almost exactly like the one in OOTP16, which gives it a lot of points in my book. Another positive that it has with me is that it is easy to find your team and the farm teams with the new menu's, it saves time and it also saves probelms that you might have. The trades, OMG the trades, they are so much better in this game, and it now rivals OOTP16 trading system, it is that good. There are also expansions that you can do at the end of a season, if you would like, that makes the game feel fresher and more lively. With all of the pluses, there are some negitives that i must tell you, The major one i see so far, is the loading, it can take a long time if you even click on the home screen, i mean its not to long, but it is a wait. Another thing that i hoped got fixed but did not was the games, i really hoped for a new game screen for the games, but that didnt happen, it still looks boring and the screens can make it confusing. But other than that i really dont see anything totally wrong with this game. Overall, FHM2 is getting better, i mean a lot better, its getting up there towards OOTP, but its still years away from it

I give this game a overall score of 8.25/10 and would recommend it to hardcore hockey fans to buy it now, but causal hockey fans to wait till a sale.

FHM2 is a much more improved game than FHM2014, but it is still no where close to OOTP

reviewText:
Franchise Hockey Manager 2 is probably one of your better options for a hockey management game. While Eastside Hockey Manager is the less costly option, FHM 2 is a more polished product as of Christmas 2015 while EHM is still being developed.

Pros:

The UI is clean and straightforward.

Team names and players names are all accurate and included in the game without installation of a mod pack.


Cons:

Some scoring in the game is outlandish (with many high scoring blowouts for weaker teams or even good teams in general. You'd choose to start with a solid team like Tampa Bay on it and would steam roll to playoffs but would still have losses with a score line of 6-1 or 5-0.)


I didn't have much else to say since it's a very straightforward game. I'd give it 8/10/

It's essentially Out of the Park Baseball but with Hockey, which is what I was hoping for. Really enjoying it so far. It seems to simulate hockey great, I genuinely feel like I effect my team {mainly badly so atm :)} and it's been fun so far. I also must give them credit for adding tooltips to the stats, as someone without a lot of knowledge about Ice Hockey it has made grasping whats going on with my players a LOT quicker and easier. It was a feature I wished OOTP had, very glad they added it here :).

Only have 2 complaints about the game. The major one is the interface, it's just more awkward than OOTPB, it's workable but it can be frustrating if you're used to their Baseball games. The second isn't that big of a deal but the match interface is a little boring. Neither detracts massively from the game. Also not a complaint exactly but I wish I could just manually add jerseys and logos like you can in OOTP.

On the whole really like the game.

reviewText: I bought this as part of a bundle with OOTP 17, which added about $14.00 costs to the regular $40.00 I paid for OOTP 17. I felt I would be willing to give it a try for that price, not knowing whether I would enjoy the product or not. I tinkered around with it for a bit... setting up a historical season of my Boston Bruins from 1986. I found it a lot more clunky that OOTP... but then I do realize this FHM 2, and OOTP has 15 plus seasons of development over it. I can't comment a lot on the financials in the game, as I tend to play these types of games more as a game/season simulator, where I like to be involved at the manager/head coach level, and just get in at the game level making decisions a coach would handle. In this respect, I can say I'm not really enjoying the game all that much... most of your decision making is happening before the game with a pre-programmed set of instructions for your lines and tactics, and then the simulator just runs through that without any real imput from you as the coach in game beyond watching what happens from your pre-programmed lines and tactics. The biggest game breaker for me is the fact I can't even program any type of line matching, or make any decisions in game to put in the lines I want at the moments I would feel they need to be out there... that is one of the few things a coach can do in hockey to control the game. I really really want to like this sim and I do want to support it, so I'm kind of sorry to write a negative review on it... but just being honest, its not the game I want to play AT THIS TIME. I stress AT THIS TIME, because I think it holds so much promise... and I really hope FHM 3 will be a leap forward, and I'm hoping in the upcoming years it will become the game that I do want to play as they develop it. I can see they have every intention of taking this product as far as possible to make it the ultimate hockey simulator. I hope my small contribution will go towards development of the future game that will allow me to simulate and coach my team just the way OOTP allows me to do with baseball.

reviewText:
Pros - Depth, pretty well laid out

Cons - Changes lines randomly(I have it set up so that I manage all the lines), changes lines badly(my secondary minor league team has only one real prospect, I put him on 1st line, turn my back for a second and he is on the 4th line...have to give more time to guys who aren't as good now and have no potential to get better......also taking an offensive d-man and randomly moving his playing time up and giving him 1st unit PK time while dropping his PP time), and free agent status is messed up in some cases(I have a guy I would be looking to trade late in my first season, he will be a RFA after the season, but the game has made him an UFA, lowering his trade value). Also, trading still needs some work to get up to the level of OOTP

Only 6 hours in, and I am already sick or having to change my lines after every few games, it is taking away from much from the enjoyability of the game. I never played the first one, have gathered this was a great improvement.....but there is still a long way to go

Update - This game makes my head hurt. Seriously. It keeps changing my lines around, and then I see that the game has changed my settings(which believe me, I took great care to ensure the settings were how I wanted them and then saved). So, check your settings at the start of every season, no matter how many times you have set them and saved them....it is too late for me, but maybe I can save someone else smacking themselves in the head in frustration, which I will do many more times before I can make the Leafs a cup winner

One more issue, and it is a big one. I have a drafted player who I have signed to an entry-level contract, but I wish to return to junior. However, his team already had the maximum of foreign import players, so I can't send him to junior. He is too young to assign to minor pro, so the only choices I have are to buy out the contract and release a 19 year old first round pick, trade him, or keep him on the NHL roster, which I don't want to do because he won't play regularly barring injury. This needs to be changed so that the junior team accepts his rights back, and is then able to trade him or another player in order to get back to their limit.
